author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: It’s important to cook, wherever you are, and whatever you’re experiencing. Here are a few recipes to help.
content: The West is still on fire, and coronavirus continues to stalk the nation, particularly the Upper Midwest. Political tension vibrates in advance of the coming election. Everywhere the effects of systemic racism have been laid bare. Social isolation, meanwhile, has led to increases in overdoses, to declines in mental health, to loneliness so intense as to be personified: a new roommate, silent and angry. So many are out of work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Judith Levitt
title: President Trump, N.F.L., Leaf Peeping: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Jim Carrey Plays Joe Biden in ‘S.N.L.’ Season Premiere
description: Chris Rock hosted the first live episode since “S.N.L.” was driven from its studio by the coronavirus, and the show didn’t hold back on jokes about President Trump’s diagnosis.
content: It was perhaps the most anticipated “Saturday Night Live” season premiere in almost 20 years — the show’s first live broadcast in more than six months, hosted by Chris Rock, and its first to be produced under the new guidelines of the coronavirus era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Division Series: Faces Are Familiar, but the Landscape Has Changed
description: All four series feature division rivals facing off, but the packed schedule means regular-season tactics might not cut it.
content: One by one they disappeared from the playoffs, like naughty children on Willy Wonka’s factory tour. The Minnesota Twins plunged into the chocolate river. The Cleveland Indians turned into a blueberry. The Cincinnati Reds fell down a chute. The Chicago White Sox were shrunk on TV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: Attack at German Synagogue During Sukkot Raises Anti-Semitism Fears
description: Almost exactly a year after a far-right extremist shocked Germany by attacking a synagogue during Yom Kippur, another assault targets a synagogue in Hamburg.
content: BERLIN — A man wearing army fatigues and wielding a shovel attacked and badly injured a Jewish student coming out of a synagogue in Hamburg on Sunday, less than a year after an assault on a synagogue in the eastern city of Halle turned deadly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Pope Criticizes Lack of Unity in World’s Response to Coronavirus
description: In an encyclical, the most authoritative form of papal teaching, Francis lamented poor cooperation among countries and warned the forces of “myopic, extremist, resentful and aggressive nationalism are on the rise.”
content: ROME — Pope Francis criticized the failures of global cooperation in response to the coronavirus pandemic in a document released on Sunday that underscores the priorities of his pontificate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Storm Close In on a W.N.B.A. Title
description: Breanna Stewart scored 22 points as Seattle moved within a victory of its second championship in three seasons. Game 3 is Tuesday.
content: BRADENTON, Fla. — Breanna Stewart and an unselfish offense have the Seattle Storm on the verge of another W.N.B.A. championship.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Bob Gibson, 84, Feared Flamethrower for the St. Louis Cardinals, Dies
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 4, 2020.
content: “If you ever saw Gibson work you’d never forget his style: his cap pulled down low over his eyes, the ball gripped — almost mashed — behind his right hip, the eyes smoldering at each batter almost accusingly.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: For Trump, the Only Medical News Is Good Medical News
description: Conflicting accounts of the president’s condition underline the fact that the public does not have a definitive answer about the president’s health.
content: WASHINGTON — When Dr. Sean P. Conley stepped in front of the cameras at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center on Saturday, he delivered a briefing that seemed intended less to inform the American public than to satisfy the public relations demands of a famous and famously demanding patient — President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: New Supreme Court Term Could End Roberts’s Dominant Role
description: The possible addition of Judge Amy Coney Barrett could create “the Trump court,” pushing it rightward. Cases on the Affordable Care Act and religious objections to gay rights could offer early clues.
content: WASHINGTON — A short-handed Supreme Court — driven from its courtroom by the pandemic, grieving over the loss of a colleague and awaiting the outcome of a divisive confirmation battle — will return to the virtual bench on Monday to start a term that will present Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. with a daunting test.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Alexander Zverev’s Illness Puts French Open Health Protocols in Focus
description: After losing to Jannik Sinner, Zverev said he “shouldn’t have played” and had a fever and difficulty breathing. Tournament officials said Zverev did not report his symptoms before the match.
content: Alexander Zverev lost in the fourth round of the French Open on Sunday, but it became quickly clear after the match that he likely should not have competed at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Peter Baker and John Ismay
title: To ward off pessimism about his health, Trump releases a video from the hospital.
description: On Saturday, President Trump released a four-minute video from Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., where he is receiving inpatient care for the coronavirus, to say that he is “starting to feel good.”
content: On Saturday, President Trump released a four-minute video from Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., where he is receiving inpatient care for the coronavirus, to say that he is “starting to feel good.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Texas Attorney General Is Accused by Top Aides of Abusing His Office
description: Ken Paxton, one of the most prominent conservative attorneys general, is already under indictment. The allegations of impropriety raised in a recent letter draw intense new scrutiny.
content: Seven members of the staff of Ken Paxton, the Texas attorney general, including some of his top aides, wrote a letter that surfaced over the weekend saying he should be investigated in connection with offenses including improper influence, abuse of office, bribery and other potential criminal acts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Hong
title: Use Your Newspaper to Make a Flibber (A What?)
description: It’s a cross between a drum major’s baton, a pompom and a palm tree, and it doesn’t even require scissors to create.
content: You are forgiven if you draw a complete blank on seeing the word “flibber.” Constructed out of newspaper and resembling a crazy cross between a drum major’s baton, a pompom and a palm tree, it’s the title project of the 1964 children’s book “How to Make Flibbers, Etc.: A Book of Things to Make and Do” by the author and illustrator Robert Lopshire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: ‘Real Change’: A Race Is On to Register Ex-Felons in Florida
description: Activists armed with millions of dollars from donors like Michael Bloomberg and LeBron James are canvassing in Florida to help former felons register to vote before a deadline on Monday.
content: MIAMI — For Lucas Melton and his team of field organizers, their all-out campaign to register former felons to vote in Florida before the Monday deadline begins with informing them that they are eligible in the first place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 5, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall and Michael Gold
title: N.Y.P.D. Warns Officers: Wear Your Masks
description: As coronavirus cases rise in some neighborhoods, police officials warn officers that they could be disciplined if they fail to comply.
content: New York City police officials instructed all officers to wear masks in public or risk discipline, as the department faces mounting criticism over officers’ failure to comply with a state mandate that people wear face coverings in public when social distancing is not possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Jaime Harrison brought a plexiglass shield to his debate with Lindsey Graham.
description: Four days after a debate in which President Trump might have exposed Joseph R. Biden Jr. to the coronavirus, South Carolina’s Democratic Senate candidate, Jaime Harrison, brought a plexiglass divider to his debate with Senator Lindsey Graham.
content: Four days after a debate in which President Trump might have exposed Joseph R. Biden Jr. to the coronavirus, South Carolina’s Democratic Senate candidate, Jaime Harrison, brought a plexiglass divider to his debate with Senator Lindsey Graham.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua T. Schiffer
title: Against Covid-19, Imperfect Measures Do the Most Good
description: Speed and scale may matter more than absolute effectiveness when it comes to tests, masks, treatments and vaccines.
content: It is a basic instinct of infectious diseases clinicians and researchers to seek and prescribe prophylactics or treatments that are almost guaranteed to benefit the patients who entrust us with their care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Fear the Beard Sweat: These N.B.A. Workers Keep the Court Dry
description: Dives for loose balls. Flops to draw fouls. Soaked facial hair. They all lead to sweat on the court, and that’s a problem when N.B.A. players are running up and down the floor.
content: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — In the opening game of the N.B.A. finals last week, LeBron James of the Los Angeles Lakers toppled to the court after drawing a foul. As soon as he went down, two people wielding large towels sprang into action from behind the basket. They had one job, and it was a vital one: mop up James’s sweat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Annie Karni
title: Even without Trump, his campaign promises MAGA as usual.
description: The Trump campaign is not changing its advertising or messaging, even with the candidate in the hospital. The political operation is not bereft of leaders; the campaign manager is still helping run things from afar after testing positive for the virus. Advisers are not showing any evidence of worry, despite public polls showing President Trump still behind in key states he won in 2016.
content: The Trump campaign is not changing its advertising or messaging, even with the candidate in the hospital. The political operation is not bereft of leaders; the campaign manager is still helping run things from afar after testing positive for the virus. Advisers are not showing any evidence of worry, despite public polls showing President Trump still behind in key states he won in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: As the Miami Heat Evolved, So Did Udonis Haslem
description: Haslem, 40, has been with the Heat for all six of their runs to the N.B.A. finals. He hasn’t been a starter for years, but he remains vital to an ever-changing franchise.
content: Udonis Haslem is a rarity in today’s N.B.A.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Armenia’s Leader Makes Plea to U.S. as Conflict Rages With Azerbaijan
description: Nikol Pashinyan, Armenia’s prime minister, said he was promised a call with President Trump over Turkey’s role in the intensifying conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh. Then Mr. Trump fell ill.
content: When Nikol Pashinyan, Armenia’s prime minister, spoke by telephone on Thursday with President Trump’s national security adviser, he raised a delicate issue: Why is nothing being done to stop a longtime United States ally, Turkey, from using American-made F-16 jets against ethnic Armenians in a disputed mountain region?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Hopes Fade for New Political Course in Algeria a Year After Popular Uprising
description: “We are moving backward fast,” said a leading figure in protests last year that ousted the country’s authoritarian ruler.
content: ALGIERS — In a Moorish-style palace on the Algerian capital’s airy heights, the nation’s president proclaimed a new day for his country, saying it was now “free and democratic.” The old, corrupt system — in which he had spent his entire career — was gone, he insisted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Faricy
title: The American Dream Is Tax Reform’s Biggest Obstacle
description: The federal tax code aligns the interests of the middle class with the ultrawealthy. But the alliance may be breaking up.
content: Much of the commentary on the fresh revelations about President Trump’s tax returns has focused on how they illustrate the vulnerability of the federal tax system to exploitation by the ultrarich. This is for good reason: Mr. Trump aggressively used a set of tax breaks popular with real estate developers to pay no taxes in 11 out of the previous 18 years, and just $750 for both 2016 and 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Russians ‘Have Committed’ to Not Interfering in Elections, Trump Aide Insists
description: Robert C. O’Brien, the national security adviser, said he warned his Russian counterpart there would be “no tolerance” for interference, but didn’t mention evidence of Moscow’s influence operations.
content: President Trump’s national security adviser said on Sunday that he had warned his Russian counterpart last week that “there would be absolutely no tolerance for any interference” in the November election, but did not mention that American intelligence officials and a range of private firms had said they already saw evidence of Russian influence operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: How Does the Electoral College Work and Why Does It Matter?
description: It’s the Electoral College, not the national popular vote, that determines who wins the presidency.
content: It remains one of the most surprising facts about voting in the United States: While the popular vote elects members of Congress, mayors, governors, state legislators and even more obscure local officials, it does not determine the winner of the presidency, the highest office in the land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Apuzzo and Steven Erlanger
title: A Black Belgian Student Saw a White Fraternity as His Ticket. It Was His Death.
description: Sanda Dia’s death after an initiation ritual was regarded as a tragic accident. Newly released videos and photos have made it a symbol of growing intolerance.
content: GHENT, Belgium — Sanda Dia saw a fraternity as a doorway into a different life. The son of an immigrant factory worker, he was an ambitious 20-year-old Black student at one of Belgium’s most prestigious universities. The fraternity, Reuzegom, was home to the scions of Antwerp’s white elites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Mike Pompeo cuts visits to South Korea and Mongolia from his Asia trip.
description: As President Trump remains hospitalized with Covid-19, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will cut short a trip to Asia this week, canceling stops in South Korea and Mongolia but continuing with a visit to Japan.
content: As President Trump remains hospitalized with Covid-19, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will cut short a trip to Asia this week, canceling stops in South Korea and Mongolia but continuing with a visit to Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Kenzo Takada, Who Brought Japanese Fashion to the World, Dies at 81
description: He planned to stay in Paris for six months but stayed 56 years, becoming known for bold, exuberant prints. He died of the novel coronavirus.
content: Kenzo Takada, the designer whose exuberant prints helped bring Japanese fashion to the world, died on Sunday at a hospital in Paris. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: ‘Keep Calm and Carry On’ May Not Work in a Time of Pandemic
description: Eighty years after Londoners rallied in the face of the deadly German Blitz, many are flouting the rules aimed at preventing the spread of the novel coronavirus.
content: LONDON — During a recent visit to a private London hospital, I was horrified to encounter a delivery man wheeling in a load of supplies without wearing a face mask. An orderly in blue scrubs stood inside the elevator, three feet from me, with his mask draped around his chin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer
title: Trump Confronts a New Form of Risk, More Personal and Perilous
description: With his political career, his business dealings and his reputation, the president has long bet that he can ride out difficulties. Now, though, he is facing an entirely unfamiliar threat.
content: President Trump’s relationship to risk has often come down to an abiding self-belief: It will all probably work out for him because it generally has.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Cardinals’ Trust in Bob Gibson Went Beyond His Fastball and Slider
description: “I had a commitment to his heart,” Manager Johnny Keane once said about sticking with Gibson in a Game 7 when he was pitching on two days’ rest and coming off a 10-inning complete game.
content: It should have been as good as over: Bob Gibson on the mound in Game 7 of the World Series, facing the bottom of the Yankees’ order with a four-run lead in the ninth inning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: In Biden’s Home State, Republican Centrism Gives Way to the Fringe
description: The Republican Party’s slide from statewide power to irrelevance in Delaware mirrored its swerve from moderation to the fringe. Now a QAnon fan is running for the Senate.
content: WILMINGTON, Del. — Lauren Witzke, a dabbler in QAnon, a self-proclaimed “flat earther” and the Republican Party’s nominee in Delaware for the Senate, was exhorting her supporters last month to “Go get ’em — America First,” as they squared off against a handful of Black Lives Matter protesters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Lang Lang: The Pianist Who Plays Too Muchly
description: On a new recording of Bach’s “Goldberg” Variations, the superstar artist stretches the music beyond taste.
content: Last year Lang Lang released “Piano Book,” an album of pieces that fostered his childhood passion for the piano: short Chopin works, folk songs, “Chopsticks.” A deluxe edition includes a reprint of the score for Beethoven’s “Für Elise,” annotated with Mr. Lang’s handwritten suggestions for student pianists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The American People Need the Truth
description: The president is hospitalized. The public doesn’t need to know every detail, but they don’t deserve to be misled.
content: The American people deserve better than to be misled about the health of the president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Results, Respect and Marcelo Bielsa
description: A point against Pep Guardiola’s Manchester City felt like a victory for Leeds. But for Bielsa and his many admirers, the journey always says more than the scoreboard.
content: LEEDS, England — The spot where they filmed the scene in “The Damned United” is a wasteland now, and it has been for some time: a patch of land in the lee of Elland Road, long earmarked for some development or other. Before it was sealed off behind security fencing, a couple of excavators standing as idle sentries, it was a parking lot, and before that, it was Leeds United’s training center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: For Veterans, Bonds Forged in Battle Are Tested by 2020’s Rancor
description: Toxic rhetoric and political polarization are doing what nothing else could: driving apart ex-Marines who had one another’s backs through wars and the stresses of civilian life.
content: After surviving some of the bloodiest combat in Afghanistan, the men of the Second Battalion, Seventh Marine Regiment stayed connected on social media for support at home as they grappled with the fallout of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Mariah Carey, Elusive No More
description: A new memoir and rarities collection show the powerhouse vocalist and songwriter’s evolution into a poised, boundary-blurring pop superstar.
content: On the rainy night in the mid-1990s when Mariah Carey first kissed Derek Jeter — a tentative step away from her suffocating marriage to Tommy Mottola, the music mogul who had been crucial to building her career — the singer, drenched, returned to her waiting limo and turned on the radio. What she heard was the “grimy, dangerous, sexy-ass beat” of Mobb Deep’s “Shook Ones Pt. II,” one of the crucial New York rap statements of all time, the sort of desolate song that can drop the temperature 20 or 30 degrees in an instant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Ron Johnson continues to oppose mask mandates after testing positive for the coronavirus.
description: Senator Ron Johnson, the Wisconsin Republican who tested positive for the coronavirus this week and whose state has experienced a recent record surge in virus cases, said on Saturday that he continues to oppose mask-wearing mandates.
content: Senator Ron Johnson, the Wisconsin Republican who tested positive for the coronavirus this week and whose state has experienced a recent record surge in virus cases, said on Saturday that he continues to oppose mask-wearing mandates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘David Attenborough: A Life on Our Planet’ Review: Ruin and Regrowth
description: In this moving documentary, the famed naturalist maps how steeply the planet’s biodiversity has diminished over his lifetime.
content: The majestic documentary “David Attenborough: A Life on Our Planet” opens with its title subject standing in a deserted location. It’s the territory around the Chernobyl nuclear plant, a once buzzing area that was evacuated after human error rendered it uninhabitable. Only later will the directors, Alastair Fothergill, Jonnie Hughes and Keith Scholey, pull their camera back to reveal that the territory, in its vacancy, has grown into a lush wildlife paradise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: 1 Dead and 2 Are Injured as Seaplane Slams Into Pier in Queens
description: The plane, “traveling rather fast along the water, skipped twice and hit the pier,” the New York fire commissioner said.
content: One person was killed and two were seriously injured when a seaplane they were in crashed into a concrete pier in Whitestone, Queens, on Sunday, fire officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: At the White House, an Eerie Quiet and Frustration With the Chief of Staff
description: With President Trump hospitalized, Mark Meadows, the White House chief of staff, delivered no guidance to aides about how they were expected to behave in a moment of crisis.
content: WASHINGTON — In a memo to his senior staff on Friday morning, Marc Short, Vice President Mike Pence’s chief of staff, encouraged everyone to stay away from their offices in the Old Executive Office Building while contact tracing was going on. On Saturday, he held an all-staff conference call to discuss what the coming weeks would look like while President Trump remained under treatment for the coronavirus, and later reiterated the message that staff members were to work from home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales and Allyson Waller
title: A Timeline of Trump’s Symptoms and Treatments
description: What is known so far about what happened in the days leading up to the president’s hospitalization.
content: As President Trump continues to be treated at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center, doctors and senior White House staff members have given conflicting updates about the president’s condition, treatments and when he learned he was infected with the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: Identify the Different Symptoms of the Flu and Covid-19
description: With fears of a “twindemic” in the United States this fall, here’s a guide to understanding what’s making you feel terrible.
content: As influenza season approaches, some Americans, and especially parents, are worried that, if they or their children should become ill, it may not be easy to know which disease they have — the flu or Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo and Hilary Moss
title: Try ‘Comedy Pilates’ and Celebrate Indigenous Cultures
description: This week, dive into the British Museum’s artifact collection, make art out of leftover veggies and revisit the myth of the Loch Ness monster.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenni Russell
title: America, We Know What You’re Going Through
description: The lessons from Boris Johnson’s bout with Covid.
content: America, we’ve been here before you. We know what it is like to have a country’s leader downplay the virus, ignore safety measures inside their work space, assume health restrictions are for the little people, and then become ill. We know what it’s like to be pitched into fearful political uncertainties; who’s making the decisions in a crisis, and what are the consequences for us if a leader is incapacitated?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: The Best Live Animal Feeds From Around the World
description: Research shows that watching footage of them can make you happier, so here’s a list of round-the-clock camera footage that will bring koalas, penguins and puppies straight to your screen.
content: If you spend hours scrolling through cat videos online, there’s a scientific explanation for why that’s a hard habit to kick: A new study has found that watching footage of cute animals can reduce your anxiety, blood pressure and heart rate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Margalit
title: Lockdown Feels Pretty Different the Second Time Around
description: Israel has become the first country to reimpose a full national lockdown. This one is nothing like the first.
content: TEL AVIV — When Israel imposed a coronavirus lockdown in March, I walked home after raiding the supermarket and was able to hear the birds chirping on Dizengoff Street, one of the busiest arteries here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: For Second Straight Game, Giants Are Kept Out of the End Zone
description: An interception ended the Giants’ fourth-quarter push, and a postgame fight marred the Rams’ 17-9 win on Sunday in Inglewood, Calif.
content: INGLEWOOD, Calif. — Jared Goff hit Cooper Kupp for a 55-yard touchdown with less than seven minutes to play, and the Los Angeles Rams grinded out a 17-9 victory over the Giants on Sunday in a game marred by a postgame fight between Rams cornerback Jalen Ramsey and Giants receiver Golden Tate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Simona Halep Upset in French Open by Iga Swiatek
description: Swiatek bounced Halep, the top seed, in straight sets in the fourth round to deliver the biggest surprise so far in a women’s draw that has been upended.
content: The French Open women’s tournament, already a spinning roulette wheel of upsets and unlikely success stories, got its first genuine shock on Sunday when unseeded Polish youngster Iga Swiatek upset No. 1 seed Simona Halep 6-1, 6-2 in the fourth round.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Dish From a Crockpot
description: Evan Mahnken whips up a toothsome Monday morsel.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — There is a phenomenon known as the consummate Monday puzzle, one that is made for new solvers. It does not color outside the lines or demand that your Monday brain make unnecessary contortions. It is logical and simple, and the pieces fall into place with ease. This is what Evan Mahnken has delivered to us. Try it with the confidence that your week will kick off with at least one success assured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: For veterans, toxic rhetoric and political polarization are a new source of division.
description: After surviving some of the bloodiest combat in Afghanistan, the men of the Second Battalion, Seventh Marine Regiment stayed connected on social media for support at home as they grappled with the fallout of war.
content: After surviving some of the bloodiest combat in Afghanistan, the men of the Second Battalion, Seventh Marine Regiment stayed connected on social media for support at home as they grappled with the fallout of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chanelle Benz
title: Comics That Dismantle the White Cowboy Myth
description: In “Black Heroes of the Wild West,” James Otis Smith introduces a new audience to Stagecoach Mary, Bass Reeves and Bob Lemmons.
content: BLACK HEROES OF THE WILD WESTBy James Otis SmithIntroduction by Kadir Nelson
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘In 1973, I Yelled Out to Elston Howard, the Former Yankees Catcher’
description: Spotting famous people on the street, a night outside the Met and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: 6 Ways to Celebrate Halloween From Behind the Wheel
description: Drive-in horror film screenings and fright-night experiences are popping up around the country for a pandemic-safe holiday.
content: From “Christine” to “Crash!,” the killer car movie is a hallowed horror subgenre. Pick your vehicle — bulldozer, hearse, big rig — and there’s a scary movie about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Officials offer conflicting accounts of Trump’s health.
description: When Dr. Sean P. Conley delivered a briefing at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center on Saturday, it seemed intended less to inform the American public than to satisfy the public relations demands of a famous and famously demanding patient — President Trump.
content: When Dr. Sean P. Conley delivered a briefing at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center on Saturday, it seemed intended less to inform the American public than to satisfy the public relations demands of a famous and famously demanding patient — President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jori Finkel
title: Jenny Holzer App to Bring ‘Great Books’ Home
description: The project, commissioned by the University of Chicago, will let users virtually project thought-provoking quotes from its Core Curriculum onto their surroundings.
content: For decades, the artist Jenny Holzer has projected phrases — often borrowed sayings — on surfaces such as building facades, ocean waves and mountains. But her new project, called “You Be My Ally” after a line by Sappho, includes her first smartphone app designed to let users at home superimpose some loaded quotes on their own surroundings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Can Halloween Be Saved? Yes, Experts Say. Here’s How.
description: You can still safely celebrate the ghoulish season, but trick-or-treating and other celebrations may have to be modified to protect against coronavirus infection.
content: It had already been a hard year for kids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: The presidential race enters a new period of uncertainty with Trump sidelined indefinitely.
description: With President Trump sidelined indefinitely less than a month before the election, the race has entered a new period of uncertainty.
content: President Trump’s hospitalization has plunged an already volatile race into extraordinary uncertainty, sidelining the president indefinitely with a month until Election Day and making the pandemic a more urgent and delicate issue for Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein, Daniel E. Slotnik, Eliza Shapiro and Liam Stack
title: Fearing 2nd Wave, N.Y.C. Will Adopt Restrictions in Hard-Hit Areas
description: “Today, unfortunately, is not a day for celebration,” the mayor said of rising virus rates. His plan would affect 20 neighborhoods in Brooklyn and Queens.
content: For many weeks, public health officials had expressed concern that a second wave of the coronavirus would hit New York City, which until recently had achieved striking success in beating back the outbreak after a devastating spring that left more than 20,000 residents dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel, Bill Pennington, Ken Belson and Benjamin Hoffman
title: N.F.L. Week 4: Bills Go to 4-0 With Win Over Raiders
description: Josh Allen and the Buffalo Bills have their best start to the season since 2008.
content: The idea of “tests” in the N.F.L. is usually a figurative one — how will Team X respond to the test of So-and-So’s defense? Until this week, pro football had been blissfully unencumbered by the scrambling and rescheduling to deal with positive coronavirus tests that other leagues have dealt with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2020 French Open: What to Watch on Sunday
description: As the round of 16 gets underway, Rafael Nadal and Simona Halep are featured against a pair of players with bright futures.
content: How to watch: 5 a.m. to noon on the Tennis Channel; streaming on the Tennis Channel app and, starting at 11 a.m., on Peacock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: With ‘The Searcher,’ Tana French Ventures Into New Territory
description: The beloved crime novelist has written a Western-inflected mystery with her first American protagonist and a back story that touches on police violence and systemic racism.
content: Ever since she released her debut novel, “In the Woods,” Tana French has drawn such a devoted following that it borders on cultish. In the last 13 years, she has published seven novels that won over millions of fans with their twisty, nuanced plots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bianca Giaever
title: One Million Lives
description: Remembering the people who died from the coronavirus — through those who loved them.
content: When we began this episode, we imagined an audio obituary — a celebration of the one million lives that we’ve lost to the coronavirus. But then, we picked up the phones. We called the friends and family who loved these people in the ugly, messy, tender way that love works. The phone calls were breathy and raw. Quiet. There was laughing, crying, heaving and sobbing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson, Maggie Haberman, Nicholas Fandos and Lisa Lerer
title: McConnell says Senate won’t meet as planned after a third senator tests positive.
description: Mitch McConnell says Senate won’t meet as planned after a third senator tests positive.
content: Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, announced on Saturday that the Senate would not meet as planned next week after three senators tested positive for the virus, but indicated that Republicans would press ahead to confirm Judge Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court without delay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Snooker, Handball, N.B.A.? It’s the Craziest Sports Calendar Ever
description: It’s not your imagination. This glut of sports events is kind of epic.
content: Remember when all there was to watch was South Korean baseball and cherry-pit spitting?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: President Trump, undergoing an experimental antiviral treatment, spends a third day in the hospital.
description: A barrage of conflicting accounts created confusion about his medical condition. Mr. Trump released a video from Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., projecting optimism.
content: President Trump entered his third day in the hospital on Sunday after contracting the coronavirus and falling ill last week, even as confusing and contradictory accounts about his medical condition added to the national sense of uncertainty and concern for the 74-year-old president’s well-being.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
title: Bright Lights of Dubai Beckon Israel’s Arabs but Pose a Quandary
description: Diplomatic ties with the U.A.E. and Bahrain could create new opportunities. But many say they are loath to undercut the Palestinian cause.
content: JERUSALEM — For Israel’s Arab citizens, the normalization deals that Israel struck with the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain will mean newfound freedom to stroll through Dubai’s cavernous malls, take lucrative jobs in Abu Dhabi or solicit investments from wealthy Emiratis or Bahrainis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: A Sick Twist for the Economy
description: President Trump’s coronavirus diagnosis throws markets — and his campaign — into turmoil.
content: Just when it seemed like the country’s pandemic recovery — and the upcoming elections — couldn’t get any more surreal, here we are. Read on for the business and tech news you need to know for the week ahead, and be safe out there. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Trump’s illness, US-India ties, Kenzo: Here’s what you need to know.
content: In a video message from the Walter Reed military medical complex, President Trump said he was “starting to feel good” but acknowledged that the coming days would reveal the severity of his coronavirus infection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jewell Parker Rhodes
title: From Sharecropping to the Voting Booth in 3 Generations
description: In “Loretta Little Looks Back,” a novel in monologues, Andrea Davis Pinkney invites young readers to “go tell it” by reciting along with the characters.
content: LORETTA LITTLE LOOKS BACKThree Voices Go Tell ItBy Andrea Davis PinkneyIllustrated by Brian Pinkney
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Warm Up With Cider Cocktails
description: With fresh or hard cider on hand, you have the makings of all sorts of drinks.
content: Amber is the color of autumn in a glass, with the tender blush of a Bellini giving way to sturdier, warming whiskey-based drinks. But it’s also time for cider, now on the upswing. Cider is not only a sweetly refreshing family quaff; when fermented and alcoholic, it’s also a delicious alternative that competes with beer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Black Germans Say It’s Time to Look Inward
description: The Black Lives Matter movement saw shows of solidarity around the world this summer. In Germany, some feel there is a reluctance to acknowledge more local problems.
content: BERLIN — In June, when Jelisa Delfeld joined a Telegram channel to help organize a silent demonstration against racism in Stuttgart, Germany, she was one of fewer than two dozen members. The next day, that number grew to 100, and the following, about 1,000 people had joined the channel where the protest was being planned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas and Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Trump’s Treatment Suggests Severe Covid-19, Medical Experts Say
description: Many of the measures cited by his doctors are reserved for patients severely affected by the coronavirus.
content: President Trump’s doctors offered rosy assessments of his condition on Sunday, but the few medical details they disclosed — including his fluctuating oxygen levels and a decision to begin treatment with a steroid drug — suggested to many infectious disease experts that he is suffering a more severe case of Covid-19 than the physicians acknowledged.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Luke Combs’s Country Stardom and the Remaking of the Bro
description: The Nashville singer and songwriter learned from the genre’s past and carved his own path.
content: Luke Combs has put out two albums in the last three years — both remained firmly entrenched in the Top 5 of the Billboard country album chart since their release. His stranglehold makes him the most promising and influential new country star of the last five years, something he’s achieved by learning from the sins of the genre’s recent past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton DiSclafani
title: Politics as an Act of Love
description: As a liberal in the Deep South, I am in the minority, but I persist.
content: AUBURN, Ala. — Since August, I’ve been in charge of Senator Doug Jones’s campaign sign delivery for greater Lee County, which is in the eastern part of Alabama. I receive a list of people who have requested signs from the senator’s headquarters, in Birmingham. I then spend a lot of time on Google spreadsheets and Google maps, dividing the requests into routes and sending the routes to our stable of volunteers. The problem is that we have too many people who want to deliver signs and not enough people who want signs. There’s always a disappointed volunteer, someone who wasn’t fast enough on the draw.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 4, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Oct. 4, 2020.
content: An article this weekend on Page 4 about pop-up comedy shows in the city misspelled the surname of a comedian and activist in New York. Her name is Kambri Crews, not Krews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Virus diagnosis and secret texts upend a critical Senate race in a single night.
description: Even for an election cycle defined by a relentless string of crises and chaos, the amount of time it took for the Senate race in North Carolina, which could determine which party controls the Senate, to fall into utter mayhem was something of a record.
content: Even for an election cycle defined by a relentless string of crises and chaos, the amount of time it took for the Senate race in North Carolina, which could determine which party controls the Senate, to fall into utter mayhem was something of a record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Sick With Covid, Trump Tries to Paint the Picture of Health on TV
description: Over an unprecedented weekend, the hospitalized president relied on very familiar image-making.
content: Donald J. Trump has told aides to think of every day of his administration as an episode in a television show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: New York to ‘Rewind’ Re-Opening in Hard-Hit Neighborhoods
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York announced plans to close nonessential businesses, schools and day care centers in nine neighborhoods where the coronavirus testing positivity rates have been higher than 3 percent in the past 7 days.
content: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York announced plans to close nonessential businesses, schools and day care centers in nine neighborhoods where the coronavirus testing positivity rates have been higher than 3 percent in the past 7 days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Trump Waves To Supporters Outside Walter Reed Hospital
description: President Trump, who has been hospitalized since Friday at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center, drove by and waved to supporters outside the facility. In a new video, he said he had “learned a lot about Covid.”
content: President Trump, who has been hospitalized since Friday at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center, drove by and waved to supporters outside the facility. In a new video, he said he had “learned a lot about Covid.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Lett
title: Podcasts to Inform Your Vote
description: An educated citizenry is vital for the Republic’s survival. These podcasts offer a good place to start.
content: The same year George Washington took the oath of office to become the first president of the United States, Thomas Jefferson sent a letter to the Welsh philosopher Richard Price in which he described the newly created government.  Jefferson wrote, “Wherever the people are well-informed they can be trusted with their own government.” The future third president most likely never imagined our era of disinformation, when an informed citizenry is perhaps more important than ever. Here are four podcasts to help you better understand how American democracy works and your role in keeping it alive.
source.name: The New York Times

title: I’m Black, and I Joined a Vaccine Trial
description: A writer is aware of racism in medicine, but felt that volunteering was “the only way we will get out of this pandemic.” Also: In Japan, a step toward gender equality.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Can We Reconcile Faith and Politics?
description: Readers offer strong views of a recent column by David Brooks.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
